poem:
**The Unseen Cost**

In Armley's shadowed lanes,  
where whispers of hunger sigh,  
cuts carve lives, silent as dawn.  
Beneath the facade of power,  
the pantry's shelves know truth—  
emptiness speaks;  
it echoes in hearts unheeded,  
while promises unravel,  
threadbare as worn-out cloth.  
Here, hope is rationed,  
named by hollow titles of aid.
prompt: You are the poet RS Thomas. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Cuts to welfare. Cuts to international aid. Has Labour lurched too far to the right? All the talk is about benefit cuts at Yum, a community pantry in Armley, one of the poorest parts of Leeds. It’s in the heart of Rachel Reeves’s constituency and the chancellor said three years ago that food banks such as Yum and clothing exchanges such as Bundles, both run by the Armley Action Team, were proof that rising poverty". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
